CTX.coveredRegionalRequirements:
• Content of communication: Theoretical and complex subject areas, also of a more scientific nature, related to students' education, chosen specialisation area, societal issues and working life; thoughts, opinions, ideas, experiences and feelings; cultural expressions in modern times and historically, such as literary periods.
  • Content of communication: Societal issues, cultural, historical, political and social conditions, and also ethical and existential issues in different contexts and parts of the world where English is used.
  • Reception: Spoken language, also with different social and dialect features, and texts, including complex and formal texts which relate, discuss, argue, report, describe and investigate, also via film and other media.
  • • Reception: Texts of different kinds and for different purposes, such as agreements, in-depth articles and scientific texts.
  • Production and interaction: Oral and written production and interaction in different situations and for different purposes where students argue from different perspectives, apply, reason, assess, investigate, negotiate and give reasons for their views.
  • Production and interaction: Processing of language and structure in their own and others' communications, in formal and complex contexts, and to create adaptation to genre, style and purpose.

thumbnailAssetId.name: Image of businesswoman of the future working with media screen

lessonObjectives:
You’re going to:

  • write a review of a film based on a short story.
  • practise words and phrases used in film reviews.

vocabulary.definition: to prove to be good, popular, etc. over a long period of time
not showing enough natural expression, emotion or movement
a person who strongly opposes somebody/something
a very famous person, especially in a particular field, who is admired by other people
the things that are supposed to have happened to the characters in a film/movie, novel, etc, before the film/movie, etc. starts
done without any good reason or purpose and often having harmful effects
if a joke, a story, or an event falls flat, it completely fails to amuse people or to have the effect that was intended
making people think seriously about a particular subject or issue

title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
Please note that the Writing section in this unit spans two 55-minute lessons. This is to provide enough time for students to write their reviews. Students will be required to read a short story and watch a film before writing their reviews (see the Plan activity). Providing access to the stories and films, as well as giving students time to read and watch them, will require some prior planning. 

Encourage students to guess. The purpose of this activity is to generate discussion. It is not important if students get the answers wrong.

Extension

Students could discuss whether they have seen any of the films and give their opinions on them. They could also discuss whether they have encountered the things that inspired these films.

Students could also discuss other sources of inspiration for films, for example: autobiographies, plays, short stories, and older films that are remade.
playlistItems.authoringNotes:
Time sensitive: All of these films were relevant as of July 2015, but will date quickly.

Refers to:

  • Films based on short stories: A review; Plan

Submitted for review: Sources:

  • http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/sep/10/23-jump-street-channing-tatum-jonah-hill
  • http://www.britannica.com/topic/Pirates-of-the-Caribbean-The-Curse-of-the-Black-Pearl
playlistItems.title: Warm up

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: What do you know about Hollywood films? Match the films to the things that inspired them.

activities.objectivesText:
You’re going to:

  • write a review of a film based on a short story.
  • practise words and phrases used in film reviews.

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
Recommend students go to imdb.com if they need help with online research.

Suggested answers

  1. Students will have their own answers.
  2. The films are all science fiction films. They are usually ‘high concept’ films (that is, they are based around a single, interesting idea). Most of the films are also action thrillers. They are usually set in a dystopian world, in which one man is fighting against an oppressive system. The lead role in each film is played by a male Hollywood star (Keanu Reeves, Harrison Ford, Tom Cruise, Nicolas Cage, Matt Damon, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Colin Farrell).
  3. Students will have their own answers.

Extension

If there is time, students could watch trailers for the films they haven’t seen.

Students could also look at the 2015 TV series The Man in the High Castle based on the 1962 Philip K. Dick novel of the same name.

items.discussionTopics: Have you seen any of these films? Give your opinion about any of the films you have seen.
Look online for information about these films. What are some of the similarities between them?
Would you like to see any of these films? Explain your answer.

playlistItems.authoringNotes: Time sensitive: If further films are made based on the work of Philip K. Dick, they should be added to the list.
playlistItems.title: Lead in

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: Look at the list of films based on the writing of US author Philip K. Dick. Then discuss the questions.

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
Any answers that are close to the model answers are acceptable.

Language notes

  • A conspiracy is a secret plan to do something bad.
  • A person that shows vulnerability shows that he or she can be easily hurt mentally or physically.
  • Someone who is psychic has special mental powers such as the ability to know what other people are thinking, or the ability to predict the future.

prompt.text: What similarities are there between the short story and the film according to the review?

answers: The short story and the film are both set in the future. They both have the same basic plot.

prompt.text: What differences are there between the short story and the film according to the review?

answers: In the short story, the character of Anderton is older, the technology is more old-fashioned, and the plot is less complicated.

prompt.text: What positive things does the writer say about the film?

answers: The film is intelligent. The acting is very good. The film’s vision of the future is impressive. The film is entertaining and thought-provoking.

prompt.text: What negative things does the writer say about the film?

answers: The plot is too complicated. There are unnecessary scenes. The ending is not successful.

prompt.text: What recommendations does the writer make about the film and the short story?

answers: The film is well worth watching. It is also a good idea to read the original short story.

playlistItems.authoringNotes: Reference to a specific market: The review mentions the nationality of the two Swedish actors in Minority Report (Max von Sydow and Peter Stormare). These references can be removed for other markets if this feels unnatural.
playlistItems.title: Read

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: Read the review of the film Minority Report and answer the questions.

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
Tell students not to use their dictionaries. 

If necessary, explain how to guess the meaning of words from context or have students read the reference material.

Variation

Students can complete the activity without reading the text. 

Language notes

  • The main character in a story is called the protagonist. This is the person who opposes the antagonist.
  • A variety of words can be used with ‘plot’ when talking about stories, for example: a plot hole is something in a plot that makes no sense; a plot device is something that happens to move the plot forward; a plot line gives the main elements of a plot.

matchItems.answer: to continue to be popular after many years (phrase)
a famous person who is admired for doing something well (noun)
when a joke or story fails to have the planned effect (phrase)

playlistItems.title: Language

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: Study the key language in bold within the film review. Then match the words and phrases to the definitions.

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
This practises the words and phrases from the Language activity. 

Language notes

Source material is the original document, book, etc. that is used to provide information or ideas. The source material for a film could be a novel or play, for example.

Extension

Students could discuss whether they would like to see this film.

items.markedGapsText:
Review: For Your Eyes Only

While I am a fan of James Bond, some older Bond films aren’t great and haven’t really stood the test of time. One of these films is 1981’s For Your Eyes Only.

This film is based on two short stories by Ian Fleming: ‘For Your Eyes Only’ and ‘Risico’. These tales form two plot strands within the film. In the first story, Bond meets the beautiful assassin, Melina Havelock. In the second, Bond is caught in a battle between two crime bosses: Colombo, and his antagonist Kristatos.

While the source material used in For Your Eyes Only is strong, the main problem with the film is the acting. Although the James Bond of Fleming’s stories is tough, Moore plays Bond as a cheerful joker (although most of his jokes fall flat). In addition, French model Carole Bouquet, who plays Melina Havelock, clearly can’t act, and seems wooden and lifeless throughout the film. The only decent performance is provided by the great cinema legend Topol, who plays the part of Columbo.

Another issue is the film’s overall plot — or lack of it. The film moves from one gratuitous action sequence to another for no real reason, with stunts involving helicopters, toboggan runs, dune buggies, submarines, and even a fight with an ice hockey team!

Recent Daniel Craig Bond films like Skyfall have been intelligent and thought-provoking. They have even provided Bond with a fascinating backstory, telling us about his parents and his home. For Your Eyes Only, in contrast, is a mess. I suggest reading the stories and forgetting the film.

playlistItems.authoringNotes:
Refers to:

  • Films based on short stories: A review; Language
playlistItems.title: Practice

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: Fill in the gaps to complete the film review.

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
Students may need help with locating films and short stories. Some older stories (such as those by Conan Doyle, Dickens, Fitzgerald, and Irving) will be available online from sources like Project Gutenberg (https://www.gutenberg.org/). Some films may be available via streaming services.

Have students decide which film to choose by researching them online. Recommend students go to http://www.imdb.com if they need help with online research. Please feel free to shorten the list of films, or add to it if necessary.

Students should be made aware that the stories the films are based on vary in length and complexity.

If there is time in the lesson once students have chosen, located, and researched the stories and films, they can begin to read the stories. Ideally students will finish reading the stories and watching the films outside the classroom. However, time could be allocated to this in a lesson, depending on the classroom situation.

Variation

Students could watch a film based on a novel they are studying, and write a review on it.

Students could look at other forms of source material, and watch films based on them, for example: comic strips, non-fiction books, plays, and TV shows.

items.discussionTopics:
Choose a film to review from the list of films based on short stories. Then research:

  • background information on the film (its genre, director, actors, critical reception, etc.)
  • background information on the short story that the film is based on (its publication date, critical reception, author, etc.)

Read the short story and take notes on:

  • interesting elements of the plot
  • important characters
  • setting and atmosphere
  • theme and message (if any)
  • your overall opinion of the story

Watch the film and take notes on:

  • similarities and differences between the film and the short story (characters, plot, setting, theme, etc.)
  • the acting
  • the dialogue
  • style and design (costume, set, sound and music, special effects, etc.)
  • your overall opinion of the film

playlistItems.authoringNotes:
Time sensitive: The list of films based on short stories was written in July 2015. It will need to be updated as new films are made based on short stories.

Culturally sensitive: Some of the films and stories have material that may regarded as inappropriate for some markets (for example, sexual content in Brokeback Mountain, Central Asian politics in The Living Daylights). Please review for new markets.
playlistItems.title: Plan

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: Plan a review of a film that is based on a short story.

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
This activity should be done once students have had a chance to read their short stories and watch their films (this may be a week or more after the Plan activity).

In the last lesson, students:

  • read a review of a film based on a short story.
  • practised words and phrases used in film reviews.
  • chose a film based on a short story to review.

In this activity students review their reactions to the story and film that they chose.

Variation

Have students discuss these questions about the short story and film that they chose.

  • What is the basic plot of the short story?
  • How is the film different to the short story?
  • What are some of the film’s positive aspects?
  • What are some of the film’s negative aspects?
  • Would you recommend the film?
  • Would you recommend the short story?

items.discussionTopics: What did we cover in the last lesson?

playlistItems.authoringNotes:
Refers to:

  • Films based on short stories: A review; Plan
playlistItems.title: Review

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.procedureNotes:
Set a word count for the reviews that students will write.

As a suggestion, students could write 250–600 words, depending on the classroom situation.

Students should use their own word processing application to plan and write their review.

Have students write their reviews, using the notes that they wrote in the Plan activity. 

Make sure that students check and edit each other’s work before sending it to you for assessment.

items.discussionTopics: Read the reference material ‘A film review’. Then plan your review.

playlistItems.authoringNotes:
Refers to:

  • Films based on short stories: A review; Plan
playlistItems.title: Produce

playlist.title: Films based on short stories: A review

playlistItems.instructions: Write a review of a film that is based on a short story.
